questions.question_text:
Universal Containers has a high volume of contracts that are renewed each year. Recently, a number of orders have failed to generate a contract despite those orders being activated and containing subscription-based products.

Where should the admin look to identify the source of the error?

A sales per at Universal Containers is trying to determine why a new Contract was unable to be created from a recently contracted Order. The sales rep has confirmed that the Order is for a new customer. This is the sales rep’s first attempt to contract the Order.

What are three troubleshooting steps an admin should take to identify the issue? (Choose three.)

choices.D: Confirm that each of the Order Products have been activated.
choices.A: Verify that the related Opportunity is in Closed/Won status.
choices.E: Check recent Apex Jobs to identify any errors in the contracting process.
choices.C: Ensure the Order Start Date is later than the Opportunity Close Date.
choices.B: Ensure there is at least one subscription-based Order Product on the Order.

choices.D: The user that authorizes the calculation service has API Only enabled.
choices.A: The user’s role should be placed at the top of the Role Hierarchy.
choices.B: The user that authorizes the calculation service is a non-human admin user.
choices.C: The user must have access to the CPQ quote and all related objects.

questions.question_text: What are two considerations the CPQ specialist should take into account when authorizing the Salesforce CPQ calculation serves for a user who is currently logged in? (Choose two.)

Universal Containers sells Tiny Boxes for $0.005 each. Tiny Boxes are Non Discountable.

How should the admin set the decimal precision for the unit price?

choices.C: Set the Unit Price Scale field to 3 on the tiny boxes Product record.
choices.A: Set the Unit Price Scale to 3 in the Pricing and Calculation Package Settings.
choices.D: Edit the Unit Price field on the Quote Lire object end set the precision to 3.
choices.B: Use a Price Rule that sets the Net Unit Price to $0,005 when the product is added to a Quote.

discussion.content:
A. Set the Unit Price Scale to 3 in the Pricing and Calculation Package Settings.
https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=000382046&type=1

Unit Price Scale does not exist as a field on Product

Selected Answer: C
Since the Tiny Boxes are sold for $0.005 each, the decimal precision needs to be set to 3 to accurately represent the price. This can be done by setting the Unit Price Scale field to 3 on the Tiny Boxes Product record. This will ensure that the price is displayed correctly on any Quotes or Orders that include this product.
